result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Raymond M Hines

records.addlTxt: Final pre-trial on December 20, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Final pre-trial on October 11, 2022 at 02:00 pm.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt:
4:01 PM Defendant Raymond M Hines appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney David R. Knaapen in court for State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Travis S Slattery in court for Raymond M Hines. 
Seth Thome is sworn as a witness and questioned by Attorney Knaapen. He is a police officer with the Grand Rapids Police Department. On 6/17/22, he was dispatched to a resident in the Town of Grand Rapids regarding a possible robbery. When he arrived, he observed a male and female walking away from the residence. He identified the defendant and he observed a wooden knife handle sticking out of his pant's pocket. The witness identifies the defendant in the courtroom. He learned that defendant was on probation and he notified Probation & Parole. Probation & Parole requested defendant be put on a probation hold, so he took him into custody. While defendant was being booked into the jail, a baggie with a white substance in it fell out of defendant's clothing. The substance was tested and it tested positive for methamphetamine. Attorney Slattery cross-examines witness.  
Court finds probable cause that a felony was committed and the defendant committed it. Not guilty plea. Bond is continued.
Final pre-trial scheduled for September 30, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on July 19, 2022 at 04:00 pm.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on July 19, 2022 at 03:00 pm.

9:01 AM Prosecuting attorney Daniel McGrath in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Raymond M Hines appeared by video, in custody, from Waupaca County Jail.
Transferred to Branch 2 for preliminary hearing. Bond is continued.
